awd_titl_txt: Promoting Early Mathematics Interest Through Playful Learning Experiences
awd_abstract_narration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Barbara Sarnecka at the University of California, Irvine, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist investigating young children's interest in mathematics. Many students from minority groups and low-income households do not pursue STEM (science, technology, engineering, and math) coursework and careers. One way to help underrepresented students persist in STEM fields is to boost their interest in STEM fields. Students' interest in math can be measured as early as preschool and relates to their later interest and achievement. Although the vast majority of young children ultimately learn the basics of counting and numbers, many children never develop interest in and other positive beliefs about math. However, little is known about how to support children's interest in math. This project will provide important insights to the fields of mathematical cognition and STEM motivation by testing whether playing math-related card games can help to boost low-income preschoolers' interest in math. 

Although much attention has been paid to supporting the early mathematical skills of children from underrepresented groups, less research has targeted children's early math interest. This study addresses three aims: 1) whether experience with a playful math activity can improve children's math interest; 2) whether experience with a playful math activity can improve children's math skills relative to a non-playful math activity; and 3) whether children's initial math interest moderates their learning from math activities. Head Start preschool children will be randomly assigned to either play a mathematical card game or complete a parallel mathematical worksheet across several sessions. Children's math interest and skills will be assessed before and after the intervention. Theories of interest development suggest that early engaging experiences lay the foundation for more stable interest in subject areas, and accordingly, this study will provide children with repeated engaging experiences to spark their situational interest. As the fields of developmental and educational psychology move towards the study of individual differences and subgroup analyses, this study will also help researchers better understand the effects of playful learning for students with varying levels of math interest. Based on previous research, the playful learning experience is expected to significantly improve children's numerical skills and promote children's situational math interest, fostering positive associations with math that could develop over time into a more sustained individual interest. The playful numerical card game is an efficient, low-cost tool that can be used to improve early math outcomes for young children, and the results of the study will be disseminated broadly to researchers, educators, and parents. Finally, this study focuses on children from groups that are underrepresented in STEM: children from low-SES households, racial/ethnic minorities, who may be particularly at risk for lower math achievement and motivation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many students from minority groups and low-income households do not pursue STEM (science, technology, engineering, and math) coursework and careers. One way to help underrepresented students persist in STEM fields is to boost their interest in STEM fields. Students' interest in math can be measured as early as preschool and relates to their later interest and achievement. Although the vast majority of young children ultimately learn the basics of counting and numbers, many children never develop interest in and other positive beliefs about math. However, little is known about how to support children's interest in math. In this postdoctoral fellowship, an emerging scholar examined whether playing math-related card games and other forms of playful math instruction can help to boost low-income preschoolers' interest in math.

Study 1 asked three questions: 1) whether experience with a playful math activity can improve children's math interest; 2) whether experience with a playful math activity can improve children's math skills relative to a non-playful math activity; and 3) whether children's initial math interest affected their learning from math activities. Preschool children from low-income households were randomly assigned to either play a mathematical card game or complete a parallel mathematical worksheet-style practice across several sessions. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, this study was translated into an online, virtual format by the design and creation of a website for children to use at home with the support of a family member. Data collection efforts were hindered by the ongoing pandemic, which has limited the bandwidth of families and early childhood education programs across the world. A follow-up study is planned to reassess these aims with a larger sample of children from low-income households.

Two additional studies were added to address the original research questions and accommodate pandemic restrictions. Study 2 asked whether elementary school students who received more playful mathematics instruction – instruction that is socially interactive, engaging, meaningful, and relevant – had higher math achievement at the end of the school year, and whether that pattern differed depending on children’s initial interest in math. The results of this study using secondary data from the Early Childhood Longitudinal Study (ECLS-K 2010-2011) indicate that children who received more playful mathematics instruction did have significantly higher math achievement at the end of fourth grade, controlling for their third grade math achievement. This relation held regardless of children’s initial interest in math. A manuscript summarizing the results of this study is currently in preparation for submission to a peer-reviewed journal.

Study 3 aimed to determine which characteristics of playful learning experiences predict students' math learning. In the initial review of 30 playful mathematics intervention studies, findings suggest that the majority of interventions met the criteria for active and engaging learning experiences, with fewer studies considered meaningful and socially interactive. To build on this work, a follow-up study will conduct a full systematic review of the playful mathematics literature and calculate meta-analytic effects of playful interventions versus control conditions, as well as the moderating effects of socially interactive interventions and differences in effect sizes by student demographics (i.e., age/grade of children, socioeconomic status, country of origin).

Thus far the principal investigator has published six journal articles, submitted two more for review, and has two in preparation about early mathematical development and playful learning during the fellowship term, contributing to her emerging research identity as expert in cognitive development and early learning environments.

Intellectual Merit: This project provides important insights to the fields of mathematical cognition and STEM motivation. Interest in STEM remains fairly consistent over time and predicts students' later STEM success, yet little is known about the factors that affect young children's STEM interest. Theories of interest development suggest that early engaging experiences lay the foundation for more stable interest in subject areas, and accordingly, this project provided children with repeated engaging experiences to spark their situational interest. As the fields of developmental and educational psychology move towards the study of individual differences and subgroup analyses, this project also helps researchers better understand the effects of playful learning for students with varying levels of math interest.

Broader Impacts: Based on previous research, the playful learning experience was expected to significantly improve children's numerical skills and promote children's situational math interest, fostering positive associations with math that could develop over time into a more sustained individual interest. The playful numerical card game is an efficient, low-cost tool that can be used to improve early math outcomes for young children, and the ongoing results of the study will be disseminated broadly to researchers, educators, and parents. Finally, this study focuses on children from groups that are underrepresented in STEM: children from low-SES households, racial/ethnic minorities, who may be particularly at risk for lower math achievement and motivation.
